questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles must carry appropriate emergency equipment, including fire extinguishers.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerB: Tires are not made to drive in wet weather.
questions.answerC: The water yet hasn't absorbed the dirt and grease.
questions.explanation: Roads are often especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Rainwater forms a slick film when mixed with oil and grease on the road surface that has not yet washed away.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you have a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: If the brakes pull to one side or the other when used:
questions.answerB: They need to be checked.
questions.answerC: They will be the most effective.
questions.explanation: If the brakes pull to one side or the other when used, it is an indication of brake trouble.

questions.question: When in heavy traffic, the safest driving speed is:
questions.answerA: Slower than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerB: The same speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: Faster than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: In heavy traffic, it is safest to travel at the same speed as other vehicles. If two vehicles continue to drive in the same direction at the same speed, they cannot hit each other.

questions.question: Backing a school bus is:
questions.answerB: Strongly discouraged.
questions.answerC: Only to be done in the morning.
questions.explanation: Backing a school bus is strongly discouraged and should only be done if there is no safe alternative. If you must drive in reverse, be sure to follow all proper safety protocol.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to adequately check all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The water compressor belt.
questions.explanation: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to check the power steering, water pump, alternator, and air compressor belts, if the vehicle is equipped.

questions.question: If you are taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take a different route.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, if your route does not include a railroad crossing, the examiner may ask you to explain and demonstrate the necessary procedures at a simulated location.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: For a basic vehicle control skills test, you are expected to be able to:
questions.answerB: Weave between a line of cones.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: School buses:
questions.answerB: Are only equipped with ABS if students who are younger than 10 years of age will be on the bus.
questions.explanation: In general, school buses manufactured after 1998 or 1999 must be equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS). Many older buses are equipped with ABS as well.

questions.question: The overhead rearview mirror is located:
questions.answerA: On the right side of a bus.
questions.answerB: On the steering wheel of a bus.
questions.answerC: Above the windshield inside a bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus. This mirror should be used to monitor students inside the bus.

questions.question: When dropping off students at a school, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Secure the bus by turning off the engine.
questions.answerB: Leave the key in the ignition, if leaving the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Read a book while students unload.
questions.explanation: When unloading students at a school, a bus driver must secure the bus by turning off the engine. If they must leave the driver's compartment, they should remove the key from the ignition. The driver must supervise the unloading process.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on specific driving maneuvers, as well as your general driving behavior.

questions.question: ABS helps you:
questions.answerB: Keep your wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: Count the number of students boarding the bus.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be score you on specific driving maneuvers as well as on your general driving behavior. You must drive in a safe and responsible manner; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and not cause an accident or commit a moving violation.

questions.question: A passive railroad crossing:
questions.answerB: Does not have any control devices.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings that do not display any traffic control devices are known as passive crossings. The decision to proceed across tracks at a passive crossing is entirely up to the driver.

questions.question: With the exception of the straight line backing exercise, a driver may exit their vehicle and check its position during testing exercises up to:
questions.answerB: Two times.
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic vehicle control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: During the driving test, when encountering a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is going too slow.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle to check for a train.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while your vehicle is on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, do not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: A post-trip inspection should include all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Looking for articles left on the bus.
questions.answerB: Checking for sleeping students.
questions.explanation: After completing a trip, a school bus driver should do an inspection in which they check for sleeping students; belongings left on the bus; open windows or doors; any mechanical or operational issues with the bus; and damage or vandalism.

questions.question: When properly adjusted, the flat mirrors on a school bus should display:
questions.answerA: The sides of the school bus.
questions.answerB: The ground under the school bus.
questions.answerC: The front tires touching the ground.
questions.explanation: Properly adjusted flat mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see 200 feet behind the bus, the base of each rear wheel, and the sides of the bus.

questions.question: The overhead inside rearview mirror should be positioned to show:
questions.answerB: All of the students on the bus.
questions.explanation: The top portion of the overhead inside rearview mirror should be positioned to display the top of the bus's rear window. This mirror positioning should allow the driver to see all of the students on the bus, including the heads of the students sitting immediately behind the driver.

questions.question: When driving a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.answerB: Before beginning to drive.
questions.explanation: You should always check the adjustment of all your mirrors before operating a school bus.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test, failing to exit your vehicle properly during any exercise will result in:
questions.answerB: An extra point against your final score.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: If there is a fire on a school bus, the students:
questions.answerB: Should stay on the bus but be moved to a part of the bus unaffected by the fire.
questions.explanation: If a school bus is on fire, or if there is a threat of fire, it is mandatory for a bus driver to evacuate the students from the bus.

questions.question: During the driving test, when encountering a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is going too slow.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle to check for a train.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while your vehicle is on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, do not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test, failing to exit your vehicle properly during any exercise will result in:
questions.answerB: An extra point against your final score.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: If students on the bus cause a disturbance while other students are unloading, what should you do?
questions.answerA: Immediately walk to the back of the bus and take care of the disturbance while students unload.
questions.answerB: Wait until the students are done unloading and then take care of the disturbance.
questions.answerC: Have a student who is closer to the disturbance handle the situation while you supervise unloading.
questions.explanation: The process of loading or unloading students from a school bus requires a driver's full concentration. If there is a behavioral issue on the bus, wait until the exiting students are safely off the bus and out of the way before you address the problem on the bus.

questions.question: After students unload at the school, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Not be concerned with the students' whereabouts.
questions.answerB: Leave after the students have entered the school building.
questions.answerC: Walk through the bus to check for any sleeping students.
questions.explanation: After students unload at school, a school bus driver should walk through the bus to check for sleeping students, hiding students, and items that students may have left behind. Students should exit the bus in an orderly fashion with the driver supervising.

questions.question: If a student drops an item while approaching a school bus, the student should:
questions.answerA: Stop and pick up the object.
questions.answerB: Have another student pick up the object.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.explanation: If a student tries to retrieve a dropped object, they may disappear from the driver's line of sight. This is potentially very dangerous. Rather than retrieve dropped items themselves, students should move to a point of safety outside of the bus's danger zones, get the driver's attention, and wait for the driver to retrieve what has been dropped.

questions.question: If you must drive during periods of high winds, you should:
questions.answerA: Loosen your grip on the steering wheel.
questions.answerB: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: A school bus's long sides are vulnerable to being pushed by winds. If you must drive in windy conditions, you should maintain a strong grip on the steering wheel, try to anticipate wind gusts, and slow down. If necessary, contact your dispatcher for instructions on how to proceed.

questions.question: When students are being picked up by a school bus:
questions.answerA: The students should wait at a designated bus stop.
questions.answerB: The driver should stop to pick up students who are walking to a designated bus stop.
questions.answerC: The parents may choose where the bus stops are located.
questions.explanation: School bus drivers may only pick up students at official stops designated by authorized school officials.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: An inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: Inspect the outside of the bus.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus. It should be adjusted to show every student on the bus, including the students directly behind the driver.

questions.question: To safely unload a bus, students should:
questions.answerA: Remain seated until they are told to exit.
questions.answerB: Stand up and head toward the door while the bus is slowing down.
questions.answerC: Exit the bus and stand directly next to the bus while it is being driven away from the stop.
questions.explanation: Students who are about to unload a school bus should remain seated until the driver tells them that it is safe to exit. After exiting the bus, they should walk to a position that is at least 10 feet away from the bus so the driver can clearly see them.

questions.question: If taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take the test again on a route that does include a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your on-road driving test route does not include a railroad crossing, you may be asked to explain and demonstrate the proper railroad crossing procedures to the examiner at a simulated location.

questions.question: The overhead rearview mirror is located:
questions.answerA: On the outside left of the bus.
questions.answerB: On the outside right of the bus.
questions.answerC: Above the windshield inside the bus.
questions.explanation: In a school bus, the overhead rearview mirror is mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side.

questions.question: At a passive railroad crossing, the decision to proceed:
questions.answerB: Is indicated by a control device.
questions.answerC: Is decided by the vehicle in front of you.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings that do not have any kind of traffic control device are known as passive crossings. The decision to proceed across tracks at a passive crossing is entirely up to the driver.

questions.question: School buses:
questions.answerB: Are only equipped with ABS if located in cold climates.
questions.explanation: Most commercial vehicles manufactured after 1998 or 1999 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). Many older buses are also equipped with ABS.

questions.question: A school bus's danger zones are located:
questions.answerA: Only to the front of the bus.
questions.answerB: Only to the rear and left side of the bus.
questions.answerC: To the front, sides, and rear of the bus.
questions.explanation: The danger zones of a school bus are areas in which children are most likely to be hit, either by another vehicle or by the bus itself. Such areas are located to the front, sides, and rear of a bus. Danger zones can extend 10 feet from every side of a bus.

questions.question: If you are taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take a different route.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, if your route does not include a railroad crossing, the examiner may ask you to explain and demonstrate the necessary procedures at a simulated location.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections should be done:
questions.answerA: Differently each time in order to place emphasis on different items.
questions.answerB: The same way each time to prevent you from forgetting anything.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: When taking the driving test and asked to make a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use a turn signal since you were told to make the turn.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only to your right.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: Properly adjusted flat mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see ____ behind the bus.
questions.answerB: 100 feet
questions.explanation: Proper mirror adjustment is vital to the safe operation of a school bus. A bus's flat mirrors should be adjusted so the driver is able to see 200 feet, or four bus lengths, behind the bus.

questions.question: Adjust a bus's mirrors:
questions.answerB: While operating the bus.
questions.answerC: At the first stoplight after starting your shift.
questions.explanation: The adjustment of mirrors should be checked prior to the start of any trip.

questions.question: To transport hazardous materials, a driver needs:
questions.answerB: A CDL with hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a tank endorsement.
questions.explanation: To drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, you must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking but the driver does not have access to a phone, they should:
questions.answerA: Drive to a phone to alert emergency personnel.
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean-up facility.
questions.explanation: If a cargo of hazardous materials begins to leak, do not move your vehicle any more than safety requires. If you continue to drive, an even larger area will become contaminated. Instead, you should park your vehicle, secure it, stay with the vehicle, and contact the proper emergency personnel. If you do not have access to a phone, you should send someone else to get help.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination.
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will be placed into one of nine classes to explain the type of risks associated with the material.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, the identification number, shipping name, and hazard class should:
questions.answerA: Be abbreviated if using a small piece of paper.
questions.answerB: Only be abbreviated if the abbreviations are easy to understand.
questions.explanation: On hazardous materials shipping papers, the identification number, shipping name, and hazard class must not be abbreviated, unless specifically authorized in the hazardous materials regulations.

questions.question: Placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: Within three inches of other markings.
questions.answerB: So words or numbers are read from left to right.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be placed on a vehicle at least three inches away from any other markings and must positioned so that the words or numbers are level and read from left to right.

questions.question: Hazardous materials may be transported:
questions.answerA: By any driver with a CDL.
questions.answerB: By a driver with a CDL and hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: In rural areas by any driver.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to operate a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may not be kept:
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s door.
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door.
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened.
questions.explanation: Shipping papers must be quickly accessible in the event of an emergency. While driving, operators must keep the papers in a pouch on the driver’s door or in clear view and within immediate reach while their seat belt is fastened. Shipping papers may be kept on the driver’s seat when the driver is out of the vehicle.

questions.question: Unless excepted, a shipping paper must list:
questions.answerB: The address of the shipper.
questions.answerC: The location of fire departments along the planned route.
questions.explanation: Unless excepted, hazardous materials shipping papers must list an emergency response telephone number.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the markings and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: All packages are labeled as poison.
questions.explanation: It is always a good idea to compare package markings and labels to accompanying shipping papers. Always make sure the shipper has displayed the correct basic description on the shipping paper and has provided the proper labels on the packages.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials must be listed first.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials must be written larger.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials must be listed in red ink.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper lists both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be entered first.

questions.question: How do you label a package if the hazardous materials label will not fit onto the package?
questions.answerA: Place the label on a tag securely attached to the item.
questions.answerB: Attach a QR Code to be scanned.
questions.answerC: Reduce the size of the HazMat label to fit it completely on the item.
questions.explanation: Shippers should place applicable diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on hazardous materials packages. If a label will not fit entirely onto a package, shippers may instead place the label on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: A hazardous material's identification number should appear:
questions.answerB: On the material's packaging.
questions.answerC: On a sticker near the material's shipping container.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It also must appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: A shipping paper:
questions.answerA: Is not needed for most shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Is required for all shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be kept in a digital file.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide proper shipping papers to communicate the risks of the materials.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.answerB: Removed.
questions.explanation: On a compressed gas tank, liquid discharge valves must always be kept closed, except during loading and unloading.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is which shape?
questions.answerB: Triangle
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: If transporting hazardous materials, a shipper should warn others by:
questions.answerA: Posting HazMat placards on their truck.
questions.answerB: Putting flashing lights on their truck.
questions.explanation: Shippers of certain kinds of hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs, known as placards, on any transporting vehicles. Shippers are required to provide applicable placards, labels, shipping papers, and emergency response information.

questions.question: The only way to effectively check your tire pressure is:
questions.answerB: By eyeballing it.
questions.answerC: By pushing on the tire to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: If accepting a shipment, what could indicate that the cargo contains hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged on wood pallets.
questions.explanation: Cylinders and drums are often used to contain hazardous materials. Be sure to take the proper precautions if transporting a cargo of hazardous materials.

questions.question: Which agency helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards?
questions.answerB: The Federal Containment Organization
questions.answerC: The United Center for Chemical Assistance
questions.explanation: The National Response Center helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards. It should be contacted in the event of a hazardous materials spill.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in the business of firework or munition dealing.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that involves such materials. Examples include paint dealers; chemical suppliers; scientific supply houses; pest control businesses; agricultural supply firms; and dealers in explosives, munitions, or fireworks.

questions.question: If you are transporting hazardous materials and the cargo is on fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to put it out with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerB: Contact emergency personnel and let them battle the fire.
questions.answerC: Hope the fire goes out by itself.
questions.explanation: Fighting a hazardous materials fire requires special training and protective gear. Unless you have the proper equipment and training, do not try to fight a hazardous materials fire yourself.

questions.question: When Division 1.3 materials are being transported, the floor liner should be:
questions.answerB: Metallic.
questions.explanation: You should use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors must be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are any metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: If a driver is given a leaking package or shipment, they should:
questions.answerB: Refuse it.
questions.answerC: Leave it on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to refuse packages or shipments of hazardous materials if they contain leaks.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: Placed in the glove box.
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: If transporting explosives:
questions.answerA: You must have a written route plan.
questions.answerB: You should take the shortest possible route.
questions.explanation: If transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you must follow a written route plan. Whenever placarded, avoid heavily populated areas, crowds, tunnels, narrow streets, and alleys. Be sure to research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: A manifest for transporting hazardous waste:
questions.answerB: Must be sent electronically.
questions.answerC: Must be attached to the outside of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting hazardous waste, you must carry with you a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest. The manifest must be signed by hand.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 materials should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.answerB: An air conditioner.
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gases), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids), the use of heaters in the same space is generally prohibited.

questions.question: You can find the identification numbers assigned to hazardous chemicals:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guide.
questions.answerB: In the truck's driver’s manual.
questions.explanation: The U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT)'s Emergency Response Guide provides information about hazardous materials, indexed by proper shipping names and hazardous materials identification numbers.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle can only be moved:
questions.answerA: To make room for other vehicles.
questions.answerB: In an emergency.
questions.answerC: If the vehicle will be traveling fewer than 10 miles.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that has not been properly placarded may not be driven, except when necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should be used only by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.explanation: When required, hazardous materials placards must be placed on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: ____ is responsible for properly labeling hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The loader
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials properly. It is a good idea for the driver to ensure the materials are properly labeled.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: The shipper
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials properly. It is a good idea for the driver to ensure the materials are properly labeled.

questions.question: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, your vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of the road.

questions.question: Who must mark and label the materials for shipping?
questions.answerB: The shipper
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to warn drivers and others about the risks of the materials by putting hazard warning labels on packages, putting placards on the transporting vehicles, and providing proper shipping papers and emergency response information.

questions.question: An indicator that cargo contains hazardous materials is:
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged in cardboard boxes.
questions.explanation: Packaging can be an indicator of whether or not materials are hazardous. Cylinders and drums are often used to hold and transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: The identification numbers assigned to chemicals can be found:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guide.
questions.answerB: In the truck's manual.
questions.answerC: In the Periodic Table of Elements.
questions.explanation: Information about hazardous chemicals is found in the Emergency Response Guide (ERG) provided by U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT). The ERG is indexed by the proper shipping names and identification numbers of substances.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be:
questions.answerA: Inside a gas station looking through a window.
questions.answerB: In the vehicle, awake or asleep.
questions.explanation: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be awake inside the vehicle or otherwise within 100 feet of the vehicle; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: When loading hazardous materials, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Load hazardous materials away from heat.
questions.explanation: Always set the parking brake before loading or unloading hazardous materials.When loading or unloading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use hooks, or any other tools that could damage containers or packaging. Hazardous materials should be kept away from heat sources.

questions.question: When loading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use:
questions.answerB: Hooks.
questions.explanation: Always protect containers of hazardous materials. When loading hazardous materials, never use equipment that could damage containers or packaging, such as hooks.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should be used only by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.explanation: When required, hazardous materials placards must be placed on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: If you are transporting hazardous materials and the cargo is on fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to put it out with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerB: Contact emergency personnel and let them battle the fire.
questions.answerC: Hope the fire goes out by itself.
questions.explanation: Fighting a hazardous materials fire requires special training and protective gear. Unless you have the proper equipment and training, do not try to fight a hazardous materials fire yourself.

questions.question: Unless the package is clearly unsafe, a driver needs ____ to accept a package.
questions.answerB: A notarized statement
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package has been prepared according to Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR). Unless a package is clearly unsafe or noncomplying with HMR, you may accept the shipper’s certification concerning the proper packaging of a material.

questions.question: Shipping papers must include:
questions.answerB: The price of the materials.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to include an emergency response telephone number on shipping papers.

questions.question: If you notice a cargo leak, you should identify the leaking hazardous materials by:
questions.answerB: Touching the materials.
questions.explanation: If you discover a cargo leak while transporting hazardous materials, use the shipping papers, label, or package location to identify which materials are involved. Do not try to touch or smell the leaking materials to determine what they are because doing so could result in injury or death.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in the business of firework or munition dealing.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that involves such materials. Examples include paint dealers; chemical suppliers; scientific supply houses; pest control businesses; agricultural supply firms; and dealers in explosives, munitions, or fireworks.

questions.question: If a package of hazardous materials is not large enough to hold a label, it should be labeled:
questions.answerB: With a tag.
questions.answerC: By being placed in a certain part of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If a hazardous materials label will not fit onto a package, it may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: How do you label a package if the hazardous materials label will not fit onto the package?
questions.answerA: Place the label on a tag securely attached to the item.
questions.answerB: Attach a QR Code to be scanned.
questions.answerC: Reduce the size of the HazMat label to fit it completely on the item.
questions.explanation: Shippers should place applicable diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on hazardous materials packages. If a label will not fit entirely onto a package, shippers may instead place the label on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: A shipping paper:
questions.answerA: Is not needed for most shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Is required for all shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be kept in a digital file.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide proper shipping papers to communicate the risks of the materials.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.answerB: Closed
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: If a driver stops and leaves their vehicle while transporting hazardous materials, the shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: Left in the front seat of the cab.
questions.answerC: Placed in a box under the passenger seat.
questions.explanation: If a driver stops and exits their vehicle, the hazardous materials shipping papers must be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: Hazardous materials may be transported:
questions.answerA: By any driver with a CDL.
questions.answerB: By a driver with a CDL and hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: In rural areas by any driver.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to operate a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the box must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerB: A return address.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages that contain liquid containers must have orientation markers. Arrows displayed on the box should be pointing in the correct upright direction.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you may park no closer than ____ from the nearest building.
questions.answerB: 50 feet
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you should not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building, unless you are parking for a short period of time while performing an operational necessity, like refueling.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is shaped like a:
questions.answerB: Triangle.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are diamond-shaped.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may be:
questions.answerA: Kept in a pouch attached to the driver's side door.
questions.answerB: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: If you discover that your cargo is leaking, you should:
questions.answerA: Touch the leaking material to identify the cargo.
questions.answerB: Use shipping papers and labels to identify the leaking cargo.
questions.answerC: Assume all the cargo is leaking.
questions.explanation: If you discover a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, identify the materials in question by using the shipping papers, labels, or package location. Do not touch the leaking material.

questions.question: What is the symbol for a marine pollutant?
questions.answerA: The image of a bird in a red octagon
questions.answerB: The image of a fish in a white triangle with an X through through the fish
questions.answerC: A light blue square with a dark blue X through the square
questions.explanation: The marine pollutant symbol is the image of a fish in a white triangle with an X through through the fish.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation surrounds the package and will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The package should be transported in the cab.
questions.answerC: The package should be loaded on their side.
questions.explanation: Radiation will surround each package of radioactive materials and pass through to all nearby packages. The number of packages that can be loaded together is controlled.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: The loader
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply the warning placards.

questions.question: When Division 1.3 materials are being transported, the floor liner should be:
questions.answerB: Metallic.
questions.explanation: You should use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors must be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are any metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Get upset.
questions.answerC: Deal with it and drive at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of developing aggressive driving behavior, you should take measures to manage your stress. One strategy to do this is to simply take a deep breath and accept your circumstances if you realize you will be late to your destination.

questions.question: What helps prevent wheel lockup when braking?
questions.answerB: Air brakes
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheel lockup while brakes are being applied.

questions.question: Alcohol evaporators are:
questions.answerB: Used to add alcohol to braking systems to prevent items from freezing.
questions.answerC: Only allowed on vehicles carrying hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems include an alcohol evaporator. The evaporator introduces alcohol into the braking system to prevent the formation of ice, which can cause damage.

questions.question: An exhaust system should be:
questions.answerB: Leaking.
questions.explanation: When inspecting an exhaust system, you should verify that parts of the system are not loose, broken, or missing. The system's parts must be properly mounted and should not be rubbing against moving parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: After completing a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that the:
questions.answerB: Trailer hand brake is applied.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves and listening for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: Skids caused by over-acceleration can usually be resolved by:
questions.answerA: Removing your foot from the accelerator.
questions.answerB: Braking.
questions.explanation: A skid caused by over-acceleration can be resolved simply by removing your foot from the accelerator. Skids of this nature happen most frequently on surfaces covered in snow or ice.

questions.question: A driver who stops at a green light could be:
questions.answerB: A driver who is color blind.
questions.answerC: A person who does not know the rules of the road.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they stop in inappropriate places, such as at green traffic lights.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerB: There is no trailer.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with one or more trailers, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the trailers are straight. Mirror adjustment should be checked before the start of every trip.

questions.question: Within 10 minutes of stopping on the side of the road, you must:
questions.answerB: Alert local law enforcement.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you must place the appropriate emergency warning devices within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, you can tell that your vehicle's ABS is not working if:
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the right side of the trailer flashes three times.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights flash and then turn off.
questions.explanation: When turning on your vehicle's engine, the lights on the dash should come on and then turn off. If the ABS malfunction light stays on, the system is not working properly. In the case of a truck with a trailer, if the yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on once the engine has been started, the system is not working properly.

questions.question: When an engine is running, an acceptable oil pressure would be:
questions.answerB: 50 psi.
questions.explanation: Operating oil pressure should be between 35 and 75 psi. Do not operate a vehicle if it has oil pressure that is low, dropping, or fluctuating.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, the oil pressure should:
questions.answerA: Gradually build up pressure over the span of a few minutes.
questions.answerB: Come up to normal within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Start high, then decrease as the engine is run.
questions.explanation: Oil pressure should come up to normal within seconds of starting the engine.

questions.question: If making a tight turn, the operator of a CMV should:
questions.answerA: Be able to drive as fast as the driver of a car.
questions.answerB: Not be concerned about speed, but focus on the road.
questions.answerC: Warn drivers behind by braking early and slowing gradually.
questions.explanation: Drivers behind you may not anticipate how slowly your CMV must travel to safely make a right turn. You can help warn them in advance by braking early and slowing gradually.

questions.question: A shut-off valve is:
questions.answerA: A device that prevents air from escaping an air brake system.
questions.answerB: A substitute for a pintle hook.
questions.answerC: Another name for a glad hand.
questions.explanation: Shut-off valves are used in air supply lines to control the passage of air from one trailer to another. The rear shut-off valve should always be closed to prevent air from leaving the braking system.

questions.question: When backing up, follow a turning trailer by:
questions.answerA: Changing nothing. The vehicle will naturally follow the trailer.
questions.answerB: Changing the direction of the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Turning the steering wheel even harder in the direction that it is already turning.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, begin by turning the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn. Once the trailer starts to turn, reverse the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: When driving in hot weather:
questions.answerA: The air pressure in tires will decrease.
questions.answerB: The engine oil can help to keep the engine cool.
questions.explanation: Because air pressure increases as air expands in the heat, it is important to monitor your tire pressure when driving in very hot weather. To prevent the engine from overheating, there must be an adequate amount of oil in the engine, as well as enough water and antifreeze in the cooling system. Antifreeze is helpful for the engine in both hot and cold weather.

questions.question: When backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly to get out of other drivers' ways.
questions.answerB: Try not to use the mirrors.
questions.explanation: Driving in reverse is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind your vehicle. Whenever possible, use a helper to monitor your blind spots.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Always pump the brakes several times before holding down the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Brake normally.
questions.answerC: Press down the brake pedal as hard as possible every time you slow or stop.
questions.explanation: Drivers of vehicles equipped with ABS and drivers of vehicles without ABS should brake in relatively the same manner. When ABS is working properly, it automatically applies when brakes are applied in situations that may create lockup.

questions.question: The more alcohol in the body:
questions.answerA: The quicker the liver will digest the alcohol.
questions.answerB: The less effect the alcohol will have on the individual.
questions.answerC: The longer it will take to remove the alcohol from the body.
questions.explanation: The body removes alcohol at a fixed rate. The more alcohol consumed, the longer it will take for the body to remove the alcohol from its system.

questions.question: When driving, mirrors should be used:
questions.answerA: Only when there may be a problem.
questions.answerB: Infrequently.
questions.explanation: It is essential that you are aware of what is surrounding your vehicle at all times. You should make a habit of regularly checking your mirrors while driving.

questions.question: Wheels with welding repairs are:
questions.answerA: Safe to be used if the repairs were done by a professional.
questions.answerB: Safe to be used if the repair seems solid.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use. They should be replaced before the vehicle is taken on the road.

questions.question: To control surge when stopping, you should not:
questions.answerA: Keep a steady pressure on the brakes.
questions.answerB: Brake well in advance of a stop.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a surge in a tank vehicle, slow or stop while keeping a steady pressure on the brakes and do not release the brakes too early. Brake well in advance of a stop and increase your following distance.

questions.question: While driving a triple combination, keep the shut-off valves at the rear of the middle trailer in their:
questions.answerB: Closed position.
questions.explanation: When operating a double or triple, the shut-off valves at the rear of last trailer should be closed. All other shut-off valves should be open.

questions.question: When inspecting your tires, you do not want to find:
questions.answerA: Tire tread that is 4/32 of an inch deep.
questions.answerB: Valve stems without damage.
questions.explanation: There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on front tires and 2/32 of an inch on other tires. Valve stems should not be cut or cracked. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you have a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: What is the Johnson bar?
questions.answerA: A hand valve that works the trailer brakes
questions.answerB: A valve that indicates the fuel level
questions.answerC: A valve that limits the amount of cargo
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes. Using it while a vehicle is in motion could cause a skid.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a recommended way to spot potential signs of trouble?
questions.answerB: Using your senses
questions.answerC: Checking critical items only at the beginning and end of a trip
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly make checks to ensure that your vehicle is operating properly. Check the instrument panel and gauges; look at your mirrors; and examine the tires, cargo, and lights. Use all of your senses and be alert for anything that could be an early indication of trouble.

questions.question: A Class 1 hazardous material is:
questions.answerB: Radioactive.
questions.explanation: The first hazardous materials class includes explosives such as ammunition, dynamite, and fireworks.

questions.question: When should mirrors be adjusted?
questions.answerB: While driving
questions.explanation: Mirror adjustment should be checked prior to the start of any trip. If your vehicle has a trailer, the trailer must be straight in order for the mirrors to be checked accurately.

questions.question: An empty truck:
questions.answerA: Requires a shorter stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerB: Requires a longer stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerC: Takes the same distance to stop as a full truck.
questions.explanation: Empty trucks require longer stopping distances than full trucks because they have less traction available.

questions.question: To prevent a trailer from rolling over while turning, you should:
questions.answerB: Accelerate before the turn.
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when an operator turns too fast. Drivers should be sure to slow down before entering turns and curves, especially when pulling a trailer.

questions.question: If a vehicle is carrying hazardous cargo, placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: Only on the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: On the front, rear, and sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Only on the driver’s side of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the front, the rear, and both sides of a vehicle carrying hazardous cargo. They must be readable from any direction.

questions.question: When coupling together two trailers, you can secure the second trailer by:
questions.answerB: Setting wheel chocks.
questions.answerC: Placing it at the base of a hill.
questions.explanation: If you are attaching a second trailer to a combination, but you have doubts about the trailer's brakes, you should use wheel chocks to secure the trailer in place while coupling.

questions.question: An after-trip inspection should be done:
questions.answerB: Once a month.
questions.explanation: You should always complete an after-trip inspection of your vehicle at the end of a trip, day, or tour of duty. Complete a vehicle inspection report, if required.

questions.question: When driving, how can you maintain alertness?
questions.answerA: Keep cool by using the air conditioner or opening a window.
questions.answerB: Eat a lot of heavy foods.
questions.explanation: Strategies to avoid becoming fatigued while driving include keeping the cab cool inside by using the air conditioner or opening a window; avoiding heavy foods; and taking rest breaks about every two hours or 100 miles.

questions.question: If you doubt that you have enough space to safely drive under a bridge or sign, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive more slowly.
questions.explanation: If you are not certain that your vehicle will fit under overhead objects, you should slow down and take a different route, if possible.

questions.question: If you experience a sudden jackknife, you should never:
questions.answerB: Apply the trailer hand brake.
questions.answerC: Allow the trailer to straighten out.
questions.explanation: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should release the brakes and allow the trailer wheels to regain traction with the road. Do not apply the trailer hand brake to attempt to straighten out the rig because it will only prolong the skid. The application of brakes is what caused the wheels to lock in the first place.

questions.question: When trying to put out an electrical fire, you should:
questions.answerB: Use a B:C extinguisher.
questions.explanation: B:C fire extinguishers are designed to work on electrical fires and burning liquids. Don't pour water on an electrical fire.

questions.question: Slow down and be extra careful:
questions.answerB: When driving on dry pavement.
questions.explanation: Slow down and be especially careful when driving in and around work zones, in places where the pavement drops off sharply at the edge of the road, when foreign objects are present on the road, and on freeway on- and off-ramps.

questions.question: When stopping a manual transmission vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Push the clutch in when the engine is close to idle.
questions.answerB: Push the clutch out when the engine is close to idle.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when the engine is close to idle.
questions.explanation: When stopping, apply gradual pressure to the brake pedal and stop smoothly. If stopping a manual transmission vehicle, push the clutch in when the engine is close to idle.

questions.question: When an engine is running, an acceptable oil pressure would be:
questions.answerB: 50 psi.
questions.explanation: Operating oil pressure should be between 35 and 75 psi. Do not operate a vehicle if it has oil pressure that is low, dropping, or fluctuating.

questions.question: Operating combination vehicles usually requires ­­­­­____ operating single vehicles.
questions.answerB: About the same level of skill as
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles are usually heavier and longer than single combination vehicles. Operating a combination vehicle requires a higher level of driving skill than operating a single commercial vehicle.

questions.question: Within 10 minutes of stopping on the side of the road, you must:
questions.answerB: Alert local law enforcement.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you must place the appropriate emergency warning devices within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, you can tell that your vehicle's ABS is not working if:
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the right side of the trailer flashes three times.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights flash and then turn off.
questions.explanation: When turning on your vehicle's engine, the lights on the dash should come on and then turn off. If the ABS malfunction light stays on, the system is not working properly. In the case of a truck with a trailer, if the yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on once the engine has been started, the system is not working properly.

questions.question: If you must leave the roadway and drive on the shoulder in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerB: Get both sets of wheels onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Stay on the shoulder until your vehicle has stopped, if possible.
questions.explanation: If you must drive onto the shoulder to avoid a hazard, stay on it until you come to a stop; then signal, check your mirrors, and merge back into traffic. Avoid braking on the shoulder at speeds higher than about 20 mph. To help maintain control, always keep one set of wheels on the pavement, if possible.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.answerA: Brake normally, as you will still have functioning brakes.
questions.answerB: Pump the brake repeatedly.
questions.answerC: Press the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: Without a working Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), your vehicle will still have normal brake function. Continue to drive and brake as you normally would and have your ABS serviced as soon as possible.

questions.question: Wheel rims that have been welded should:
questions.answerB: Be placed on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe to be used.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS):
questions.answerB: Are only used on tucks carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Allow drivers to stay in control when braking.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheels from locking up during a hard application of brakes.

questions.question: An indicator that cargo contains hazardous materials is:
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged in cardboard boxes.
questions.explanation: Packaging can be an indicator of whether or not materials are hazardous. Cylinders and drums are often used to hold and transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: In very hot weather, tires should be checked regularly because:
questions.answerB: Air pressure may increase with the temperature.
questions.answerC: The tread wears down more quickly than in cooler weather.
questions.explanation: Because air pressure increases with temperature, you should pay special attention to the tire mounting and pressure when traveling in hot weather.

questions.question: What is the best way to stop if your brakes fail while you are driving downhill?
questions.answerB: Let the vehicle slow down on its own.
questions.answerC: Let rumble strips slow your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, you will need to quickly find something outside that can stop your vehicle. An escape ramp is the best option. If no escape ramp is available, use the least hazardous available option, such as driving into an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerA: Explain what you would inspect and why.
questions.answerB: Replace an electrical fuse.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be required to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. During this inspection, you must explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why you are inspecting those items.

questions.question: When driving a tank vehicle, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Make sudden stops.
questions.explanation: Because liquid tanks can be vulnerable to surge, it is important to begin braking well in advance of a stop. Increase your following distance to reduce the need to stop suddenly.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerB: The nuts are loose.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts can indicate that the nuts are loose. If you find rust near the wheel nuts, check their tightness before beginning to drive.

questions.question: In a leaf spring:
questions.answerB: Leaves can be missing.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's suspension, verify that leaf springs do not have missing or broken leaves. If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: A manifest for transporting hazardous waste:
questions.answerB: Must be sent electronically.
questions.answerC: Must be attached to the outside of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting hazardous waste, you must carry with you a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest. The manifest must be signed by hand.

questions.question: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, your vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of the road.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents a truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from driving too fast
questions.explanation: A tractor protection valve keeps air in a tractor or truck air brake system should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak. The valve will close automatically if the pressure drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: When inspecting the windshield before a trip, a person should do all the following, except:
questions.answerA: Remove and sharpen the wiper blades.
questions.answerB: Check the windshield wipers for proper spring tension.
questions.answerC: Check the wiper blades for damage.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your windshield, you should look for cracks or other problems that could interfere with your ability to clearly see the road. The windshield wiper arms should be checked for proper spring tension. The wiper blades should be checked for damage, stiff rubber, and improper securement.

questions.question: If you remain in neutral for too long while switching gears:
questions.answerB: You may have trouble putting the vehicle into the next gear.
questions.explanation: If you remain in neutral for too long while switching gears, you may have difficulty putting the vehicle into the next gear. If this happens, do not try to force the gear shift. Instead, return to neutral, release the clutch, increase the engine speed to match the road speed, and try again.

questions.question: A shipping paper:
questions.answerA: Is not needed for most shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Is required for all shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be kept in a digital file.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide proper shipping papers to communicate the risks of the materials.

questions.question: Exhaust system parts should:
questions.answerB: Rub against tires.
questions.explanation: It is essential that exhaust system parts are not leaking or otherwise broken. A faulty exhaust system can let poisonous fumes into the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: When accelerating on a surface with poor traction, such as a wet road, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Speed up slowly.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about the pavement.
questions.explanation: You should accelerate very gradually when driving under conditions that create poor traction.

questions.question: How often are hazardous materials employees required to be trained and tested?
questions.answerB: Once every three years
questions.explanation: All drivers must be trained in the security risks of hazardous materials transportation. This training must include how to recognize and respond to possible security threats. Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Tread of 3/32 of an inch in the grooves of the front tires
questions.explanation: When checking the tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, make sure the tires have sufficient tread. There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread in every major groove of the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on the other tires. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerA: Are not safe to be used.
questions.answerB: Are acceptable on combination vehicles.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable only when traveling at speeds under 40 mph.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are never safe for use.

questions.question: When checking tires, finding which of the following is not a cause for concern?
questions.answerB: Tread of at least 4/32 of an inch in the grooves on front tires
questions.answerC: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's tires, you should confirm that air pressure is neither too low nor too high; that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires; and that radial and bias-ply tires are not used together.

questions.question: In very hot weather, tires should be checked regularly because:
questions.answerB: Air pressure may increase with the temperature.
questions.answerC: The tread wears down more quickly than in cooler weather.
questions.explanation: Because air pressure increases with temperature, you should pay special attention to the tire mounting and pressure when traveling in hot weather.

questions.question: If a load is placed on one side of a trailer, the trailer:
questions.answerB: May add extra support during turns.
questions.answerC: May be easier to steer during turns.
questions.explanation: Positioning the weight of a load on one side of a trailer may cause the trailer to lean to that side, increasing the risk of a rollover during turns and lane changes.

questions.question: Baffled tanks:
questions.answerA: Are damaged and should not be used.
questions.answerB: Control liquid surge while still allowing liquids to flow through the tank.
questions.explanation: Baffled tanks contain holed bulkheads that allow liquid to flow through the tank. This helps to inhibit front-to-back surge, but does not prevent side-to-side surge.

questions.question: A tank usually has:
questions.answerB: A high center of gravity.
questions.explanation: Driving tanks requires special care because they usually have high centers of gravity. The driver should also expect cargo movement in transit, if transporting liquid cargo.

questions.question: Distracted driving can be avoided by:
questions.answerB: Smoking while driving.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.answerB: Pushing down quickly.
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: If you notice anything affecting the safety or mechanical functioning of your CMV while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay quiet and see if the problem goes away.
questions.answerB: Make a written report that includes your concerns.
questions.explanation: At the end of each day of driving, you may be required to make a written report on the vehicle or vehicles driven. Be sure to make note of any issues that could affect the safety of the vehicle or that could lead to a mechanical breakdown.

questions.question: If you must cross traffic while driving a combination vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers will make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Wait for a gap large enough for your vehicle to safely cross.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enonugh gap in traffic to safely do so.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle, rough acceleration is:
questions.answerB: Encouraged at all speeds.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in a trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.answerB: Cleaned with water.
questions.answerC: Left to air dry without washing.
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to corrosive liquids must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: To make your vehicle more visible during the day, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used for best visibility, even during the day. Using high beam headlights around other drivers can be dangerous.

questions.question: Before loading or unloading flammable liquids, the engine should be:
questions.answerB: Revved up.
questions.explanation: Unless you must run the engine to operate a pump, you should always turn off the engine before loading or unloading flammable liquids.

questions.question: If you must make a quick stop while transporting liquids, it may be a good idea to use the:
questions.answerB: Stab braking method.
questions.explanation: If you must make a quick stop to avoid an accident while transporting liquid cargo, it may be a good idea to use the stab braking method. Remember that attempting to steer quickly while braking may cause your vehicle to tip over, especially if it has a high center of gravity.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerB: Pressed down quickly.
questions.answerC: Pressed down repeatedly, but not held down continuously.
questions.explanation: When stopping, it is best to gradually press down the brake pedal.

questions.question: Fueling a bus while passengers are on board is:
questions.answerA: Recommended, but only if the passengers are told about the refueling.
questions.answerB: Recommended, but only if time is an issue.
questions.explanation: A bus should not be refueled while passengers are on board unless it is absolutely necessary. In particular, a bus with passengers on board should never be refueled inside an enclosed building.

questions.question: If you must leave the roadway and drive on the shoulder in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerB: Get both sets of wheels onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Stay on the shoulder until your vehicle has stopped, if possible.
questions.explanation: If you must drive onto the shoulder to avoid a hazard, stay on it until you come to a stop; then signal, check your mirrors, and merge back into traffic. Avoid braking on the shoulder at speeds higher than about 20 mph. To help maintain control, always keep one set of wheels on the pavement, if possible.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery when it first begins to rain because:
questions.answerB: The fresh rain mixes with oil on the roadway.
questions.answerC: The water has nowhere to go.
questions.explanation: Roads are particularly slippery when it first begins to rain. The water mixes with oil drippings on the road that have not yet washed away, creating a slippery and dangerous mixture.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, you can tell that your vehicle's ABS is not working if:
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the right side of the trailer flashes three times.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights flash and then turn off.
questions.explanation: When turning on your vehicle's engine, the lights on the dash should come on and then turn off. If the ABS malfunction light stays on, the system is not working properly. In the case of a truck with a trailer, if the yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on once the engine has been started, the system is not working properly.

questions.question: A disruptive passenger should be:
questions.answerA: Removed from the bus as quickly as possible, regardless of location.
questions.answerB: Discharged at the next bus stop.
questions.answerC: Kept on the bus and taken to the police department.
